title: Using toml version catalogs in Gradle
description: Using toml version catalogs in Gradle is a great way to manage dependencies and their versions.
author: Simon Scholz

children.value: Using toml version catalogs in Gradle is a great way to manage dependencies and their versions.

Also GitHub's Dependabot supports toml version catalogs. So it is pretty neat to maintain versions of dependencies, especially if certain dependencies share the same version, e.g., Kotlin and its plugins.
Install the Gradle Version Catalogs plugin
plugin for IntelliJ IDEA is not necessary to use toml version catalogs in Gradle, but it makes it easier to use them.

Dependabot is a GitHub feature that automatically creates pull requests to update dependencies in your project.
It supports toml version catalogs, so you can use it to update your dependencies.
Therefore the dependabot configuration file
does not need to have special treatment and can look like this:

props.className: language-yaml shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
version: 2
updates:
  - package-ecosystem: "gradle"
    directory: "/"
    schedule:
      interval: "weekly"
    open-pull-requests-limit: 10

children.value: The latest gradle version's init task already generates a toml file for you.

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
gradle init \
    --type kotlin-application \
    --dsl kotlin \
    --test-framework junit-jupiter \
    --project-name gradle-toml \
    --package com.example \
    --no-split-project \
    --no-incubating \
    --java-version 21
